newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: RALLYING-ERIKSSON BLAZES AHEAD IN NEW ZEALAND.
newsitem.headline: RALLYING-ERIKSSON BLAZES AHEAD IN NEW ZEALAND.

text.p: Sweden's Kenneth Eriksson gained leadership of the New Zealand Rally from Carlos Sainz of Spain on the opening stage of the second leg on Monday and remained eight seconds ahead at the end of the day.

As the leading drivers completed the 18th stage and the second leg, Eriksson in his Subaru Impreza was just ahead of the Ford Escort of double world champion Sainz and 32 seconds clear of Finn Juha Kankkunen in a second Ford.
Briton Richard Burns remained fourth in his Mitsubishi Carisma, one minute 31 seconds behind the leaders, after the longest and toughest leg of the rally.
Sainz held a 12 seconds lead as the cars went south from Auckland towards Pirongia for eight demanding stages, starting with the long gravel-topped 47.43 km run at Te Koraha.

But the section proved costly for the Spaniard as Eriksson outclassed the opposition. He emerged 21 seconds clear of four times world champion Kankkunen and 39 clear of the Spaniard, an effort which put him in command for the rest of the day.
Erkisson's performance -- he won two more stages later -- was a huge boost to the Subaru team after the rertirement on Sunday of former leader Colin McRae of Britain.
